_description: A rhyming proverb that serves as the opening of a letter from William Worcester to an unknown member of Sir John Fastolf’s household, Paston Letters and Papers 604; Worcester cites Aristotle’s Ethics and Cicero’s de Amicitia — one couplet

BLAdd27444.Transcription: A very frende at nedeexperience will schewe be deede
BLAdd27444.Editions:
Davis,  Norman,
                        ed.  
             Paston Letters and Papers of the Fifteenth Century.
EETS
         s.s. 20 and 21 (2004): 2.203.
